description.html:
UP IN SMOKE!  A BBQ & Bourbon Adventure

Chef Blake Jackson, winner of the 2016 Louisiana Food Prize competition, is joining forces with the folks at Kings Hardware and Gifts for a night of great food and fun.

Chef Blake will educate attendees on the fine art of smoked meats in the setting of one of Shreveport’s oldest – and most fun to look around - hardware stores with lots of locally produced items and a multitude of bbq cooking accessories.

This five course sit-down dinner will be paired with bourbon and there will even be a bourbon-miester on hand.

Salad: Grilled Hearts of Romaine topped with flash fried jalapenos and charred corn vinaigrette

Soup:  Beef and Chow Chow Dumplings in Smoked Chicken Consommé

Appetizer: Ancho Chile Salmon on White Cheddar Chie Cornbread Blinis

Entrée:  Smoked Pork Osso Bucco with Carmelized Root Veggies over Blue Corn Grits

Dessert:  Bananas Foster Pudding with Smoked Whipped Cream

PURCHASE TICKETS IN ADVANCE - SEATING IS LIMITED!

description.html:
Resonate: An evening with Drake Music | Bold. Electric. Eclectic.

An evening of audio visual delight, performances, films, improvisation and installations featuring up and coming artists from across London.

Hosted by Drake Music, showcasing the creativity and talent of disabled musicians, sound artists, composers and performers with an eclectic live show and a pop up bar.

This one-off event celebrates Connect & Collaborate London as we unveil four new commissions by disabled artists, in partnership with the London Philharmonic Orchestra, Upswing, WAC Arts and Southbank Centre.

Discover new music and the cutting edge artists and technology pushing boundaries within the music scene, from a live film soundtrack featuring members of DM Collaborate to experimental Neo-Classical Metal with live shredding on iPad and guitar.

Join us for a laid back night of new sounds and genre-hopping fun and enjoy brand new work by emerging talent from across London. 


Pay What You Decide

We want to encourage more people to see the amazing work being made by Disabled artists. Pay What You Decide not only allows you to pay what you can afford, rather than a fixed ticket price.

We would like to ask that, if possible, you make a donation a minimum of £5. The donations from tickets will support the DM Collaborate monthly meetings.

These sessions give Disabled musicians a chance to come together, share practice and jam. If you would like to donate more, please do, every penny goes towards supporting the work Drake Music does with disabled musicians of all ages.



This event, and Connect & Collaborate, London is kindly supported by City Bridge Trust and The Harold Hyam Wingate Foundation.

description.html:
It gives us great pleasure to invite you to the Drake Calleja Trust's second concert featuring selected Scholars (2016-17) and our Patron, Joseph Calleja. Extracts from our first concert, which took place in September 2016 at the Victorian Ballroom of the Corinthia Hotel London, are included in our promotional video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i2ysJuxoIRY

www.drakecallejatrust.org



The DCT was launched in September 2015 and aims to financially support and artistically nurture exceptionally talented musicians whose financial situations pose restrictions upon their studies and career. Our concerts celebrate not only our Scholars' exquisite talent but also the uncompromising standards which the Drake Calleja Trust stands for and the difference we are committed in making as an organisation in classical music.



On 20th May 2017 at the UN Ballroom of the Four Seasons Hotel at Ten Trinity Square, Joseph Calleja, Patron of the Drake Calleja Trust, will perform solo arias and duets with our singers scholars and the Trust's Head of Scholarships and Artistic Planning, Vicky Yannoula. The rest of the programme will consist of chamber music and vocal repertoire performed by selected musicians from our group of 2016-17 Scholars:


Laia Braun, violin (Royal College of Music)

Sirius Chau, flute (Royal College of Music)

Corinne Cowling, soprano (Guildhall School of Music & Drama)

Rosanna Rolton, harp (Royal College of Music)

Dominic Sedgwick, baritone (Guildhall School of Music & Drama)

Alexandra Vaduva, piano (Royal Academy of Music)

William White, clarinet (Royal Academy of Music)


The concert will consist of two halves and a drinks and canapés reception at the interval.


EARLY BOOKING IS RECOMMENDED AS THIS CONCERT IS EXPECTED TO SELL OUT QUICKLY.


www.drakecallejatrust.org



The Four Seasons Hotel at Ten Trinity Square opened its doors in January 2017. First opened in 1922, the Grade II-listed building is the former headquarters of the Port of London Authority and the original neo-classical interiors have been carefully restored, creating a seamless fusion with chic, modern design and maritime-inspired details. Within steps of the Tower of London, Tower Bridge and the River Thames, Ten Trinity Square sits in a remarkably central location. Event spaces include the UN Ballroom, an historic venue once played host to the inaugural reception of the United Nations General Assembly in 1946, and the Merchants Hall, a circular ballroom which sits above the Rotunda.


The UN Ballroom


Four Seasons Hotel at Ten Trinity Square exterior

Just hold on we’re going ‘om.

Stretch out your muscles with some hip-hop yoga. Introducing a Drake themed yoga and brunch at Commonwealth. After an hour long vinyasa class led by our resident yogi Bronwyn Hendry, you’ll be seriously thirsty for some Champagne Papi, so stay for brunch. Sip on True Buch Kombucha Mimosa’s and enjoy a custom brunch crafted by Chef Pigot from Home and Away.

Yoga will be from 11AM-12:15PM

Brunch will be from 12:15PM-1:30

Doors open at 10:30 am, we'll be on our mats for a start time of 11am sharp.

BYOM (Bring your own mat)

The talented Chef Pigot from Home and Away will be making a sweet and savory option, we highly recommend you pre-order as quantities will be limited and food FOMO is the worst.

Yoga: $20

Pre-order brunch: $13 ( a sweet and savory option are available )

Interested in brunch, but can't commit? $15 day of.

description.html:
Michael Drake is masterIT’s founder, chairman and CEO. Under Michael’s leadership, masterIT, celebrating its 10th anniversary in 2015, has grown profitably since its inception, achieved numerous industry recognitions including the first and only mid-south provider to earn the MSPAlliance Accreditation, The MSPmentor 100 and 501 – the industry’s ranking of the most successful managed service providers globally seven years in a row, and CRN Magazine’s 40 Most Innovative MSP’s in North America. The Memphis Business Journal also named masterIT a 2013 finalist for Business of the Year. In 2012, Michael was named to MSPmentor’s inaugural industry Hall of Fame class, and he was a finalist for Memphis Business Journal’s Executive of the Year. Inside Memphis Business Magazine has named Michael to it’s Power Players Edition from 2011-2015. Michael is a 1986 graduate of the University of Memphis with a BBA in Finance and held various banking positions in the mid-south prior to joining Econocom-USA in 1990.

He is a frequent keynote and industry speaker at such national and international events as TEDx, CompTIA and MSPtv as well as industry summits including N-able, Autotask and TruMethods.

 

FAQs

 

Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?

Please call 901-765-4652.

 

Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?

No.

description.html:
$50 Member Price / $60 Non-Member Price 

Interested in becoming a member of PRNSA? Click Here! 



The peak wildflower bloom is an excellent time for an eight-mile walk through the Estero Trail’s diversity of wildflowers and plants. We will stop to view grebes, scoters, shorebirds, and other waterbirds migrating and feeding in the rich estuaries. Expect to hike all day on uneven trails.


Instructed by David Wimpfheimer


-This will be a vigorous activity.

-If you have any special circumstances or questions, please contact us at fieldinstitute@ptreyes.org.



Is this event rain or shine? We use National Park advisories to determine whether or not the class will run. Click here to check out current weather conditions! 

Class Cancelation Policy: If a registered participant wishes to cancel their enrollment and receive a refund, notification must be received at least 14 days in advance of the class date. No refunds will be issued for enrollment cancelations made less than 14 days in advance of the class date. Class enrollment fees are non-transferable. In the event that the PRNSA Field Institute cancels a class, participants will receive a full refund of class fee.



What to Bring

  • Warm, variable-weather, layered clothing (waterproof windbreaker or rain jacket, hat, gloves)
  • Hat and sunscreen
  • Comfortable walking shoes
  • Daypack
  • Lunch, snacks, and water for the day
  • Binoculars (a must)
  • Camera (optional)



Interested in becoming a class facilitator to assist PRNSA Field Institute courses or becoming a volunteer for PRNSA? Click Here!

description.html:
Join a beach survey and help clean our coastlines while collecting data for a national program! 

Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary has partnered with NOAA’s Marine Debris Program and the Office of Response and Restoration in a pilot project to monitor and record marine debris. Not only is this the first project along the coast to begin monthly documentation of debris along sanctuary shores, but data from our volunteer-led surveys help inform local, regional, and national management efforts.

Summary of Volunteer work: 

  • Each month we take groups of volunteers to a permanent 100m plot located at Drakes Beach
  • Each survey lasts about 2 hours and involves the recording and removal of all debris items within each 100m plot  
  • All training and equipment will be provided (gloves, trash bags etc.)  
  • Transportation is not provided, public transport and carpooling is encouraged. Contact Kate Bimrose (info. below) for possible ride sharing from San Francisco
  • We work to ensure that volunteers have fun while learning about the scope of the marine debris problem and protecting our beaches 

FAQs

Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?

Please feel free to contact- Kate Bimrose

kate.bimrose@noaa.gov or (415)-970-5245 


Learn about our program:

http://farallones.noaa.gov/science/marinedebris.html

description.html:
Join a beach survey and help clean our coastlines while collecting data for a national program! 

Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary has partnered with NOAA’s Marine Debris Program and the Office of Response and Restoration in a pilot project to monitor and record marine debris. Not only is this the first project along the coast to begin monthly documentation of debris along sanctuary shores, but data from our volunteer-led surveys help inform local, regional, and national management efforts.

Summary of Volunteer work: 

  • Each month we take groups of volunteers to a permanent 100m plot located at Drakes Beach
  • Each survey lasts about 2 hours and involves the recording and removal of all debris items within each 100m plot  
  • All training and equipment will be provided (gloves, trash bags etc.)  
  • Transportation is not provided, public transport and carpooling is encouraged. Contact Kate Bimrose (info. below) for possible ride sharing from San Francisco
  • We work to ensure that volunteers have fun while learning about the scope of the marine debris problem and protecting our beaches 

FAQs

Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?

Please feel free to contact- Kate Bimrose

kate.bimrose@noaa.gov or (415)-970-5245 


Learn about our program:

http://farallones.noaa.gov/science/marinedebris.html

description.html:
The Unite Wales women's Committee invites you to join us at a International Women's Day Film Screening of Vera Drake.

2017 marks the 50 year anniversary of the 1967 Abortion Act. In line with Unite’s policy supporting women’s reproductive freedom, Unite Wales are holding a film screening with the Cardiff Abortion Rights group of Vera Drake at Unite House in Cardiff on 7th March at 18.00

The 2004 British drama film tells the story of Vera Drake, a working-class woman who performed illegal abortions in 1950s London. As we mark the 1967 Abortion Act, we should take time to reflect on the previous state of abortion in the UK and how we can continue to improve abortion rights for all women.

Access to free, safe, legal abortion is crucial to women’s economic, educational and social advancement and is supported by the great majority of people in Britain. Barriers to reproductive rights are barriers to full social, economic, political and workplace equality. The trade union movement has a proud history of advancing women’s rights and defending reproductive choice whenever it has come under attack

Tickets are free, but spaces are limited, to register to attend please

Gelli Plate Printing with Kasia Drake-Hames Saturday

Saturday, March 11 | 10:30 – 3:00

Get ready to experiment with this fun method of making one-of-a-kind monoprints! The Gelli printing process uses slow-drying acrylics and a plate with a soft, gelatinous surface. The process is easy and you will be able to spend the day creating layers of color, patterns, and textures on your art prints. Use them to decorate your home, make greeting cards, scrapbook materials, etc. Each participant is sure to finish this class with a stack of spectacular monoprints to take home. Bring a bag lunch for a thirty-minute break Materials list available upon registering Fee: $55 A MOWA membership is required

description.html:
Drake hat mit seinem Album “Views” dieses Jahr seinen bisher größten Erfolg feiern können. Die Single „Hotline Bling“ ging durch die Decke, insbesondere das dazugehörige Musikvideo, das im Internet für reichlich Memes und Parodien gesorgt hat. Außerdem hat der Rapper mit „Views“ als erster Künstler eine Milliarde Streams auf Apple Music verzeichnet. 

Aubrey Drake Graham alias Drake hat mit einer coolen Mischung aus R’n’B, Soul und HipHop einen aufregenden neuen Stil kreiert. Maßgeblichen Einfluss auf Drakes Rap-Stil sind Kanye West, Jay Z und Lil Wayne. Mit seinen Alben „Thank Me Later“, „Take Care“, „Nothing Was The Same“ und „Views“ feierte der Kanadier weltweit einen Erfolg nach dem anderen. Auf „Views“ arbeitete Drake mit Rihanna, Wizkid, Pimp C und Partynextdoor zusammen. 2012 spielte Drake anlässlich seiner Club Paradise Tour über 60 Konzerte in Nordamerika und Europa. Bei der erfolgreichsten Tour des Jahres waren auch Nicki Minaj, Kendrick Lamar, French Montana, Rita Ora, Tinie Tempah und Meek Mill mit dabei. 

Für das Album „Take Care“ gewann Drake einen Grammy Award in der Kategorie Best Rap Album. 2013 veröffentlichte der Rapper das Erfolgsalbum „Nothing Was The Same“, das von der Kritik bejubelt wurde und mit Singles wie „Hold On, We’re Going Home“, „Too Much“ und „Worst Behaviour“ zu einem der besten Alben des Jahres wurde. Insbesondere die Single „Hold On, We’re Going Home“ wurde zum Welterfolg und wurde mehrfach gecovert, unter anderem von den Arctic Monkeys, Lissie, Foster The People und Nick Mulvey. 

2014 war Drake mit seiner „Would You Like A Tour?“ Welttour auch in Deutschland live zu sehen. 2015 erschienen die beiden Mixtapes „If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late” und “What A Time To Be Alive”.

description.html:
Drake University Conference on Undergraduate Research in the Sciences (DUCURS):

DUCURS provides a forum to showcase scientific results of faculty/student collaborative research in math and science. The Conference on Undergraduate Research in the Sciences seeks to celebrate student and faculty scholarly engagement, recognize students and faculty work and inform the Drake community about undergraduate research generated in the science departments. The conference features the work of more than 100 students through oral and poster presentations on current research projects by students and faculty.

description.html:
The Drake University Center for Professional Studies is pleased to offer a three day program that brings a wide array of competencies supporting the art of grant writing.

 

Program Focus:

Developing a sustainable grants strategy

Finding and evaluationg grant making organizations who want to make an "investment" in your mission

Project design - delivering measurable and sustainable results

Telling the story through effective mission, goalas, and objectives

The role of the budget - how budgeting adds value to the proposal

Putting it all together and making a strong case - intepreting the Request for Proposal (FRP), persuasive narrative, organizing/formatting, engaging stakeholder support, etc.

Value of effective grant management

 

Program Designed for the Person Who...

is a member of a grant writing team or project

wants to develop grant writing skills and expand professinal and personal opportunities

is currently writing grants and seeks enhanced skills

is currently managing grants

 

Who will be facilitating?

Lance Noe, Director of the Drake University Center for Professional Studies teaches grant writing for the Drake University Master of Public Administration program .  He also serves as the instructor for the grant writing curriculum offered as part of the nationally accreditied Certified Public Manager® program.  Lance speaks at regional conferences and professional meetings bringing a message of how to best develop a sustainable grant seeking and grant writing organization.  Since 2006, he has worked as a consultant to several agencies of state and local government leading them through a comprehensive process of developing a sustainable grants strategy as well as serving as grant writer for various local and federal grants. 

 

When and Where?

The three-day, 15-contact hour program meets from 9am to 3pm at the Zimpleman Graduate and Professional Education Center, Aliber Hall/ Room 108, Drake University Campus on May 10th, 11th, and 12th.  Cost is $375 per participant and includes all handout materials.

Get ready for an exciting Saturday where teams from all over the western region of the U.S. will be traveling to Bend, OR for the second ever Bend Adventure Race. Teams of 4-6 people will meet at Drake Park with a list of various adventure challenges and a time limit of 12 hours to complete, record, and accomplish the challenges. Saturday night at 10pm everyone will be camping out (optional) to watch the top videos, announce winning teams, and reward them with RCI vacation vouchers that can be redeemed in every country around the world. You can look forward to having an unforgettable weekend that will definitely be worth talking about!

Tickets includes: Wayv Apparel Hat of your choice and Challenge List at the check-in booth

Stuff to bring: Clothes for rain and shine: a jacket, running shoes, flashlights, camping supplies such as a tent and sleeping bag, money, snacks, camera and laptop for videographers, and friends.

Stuff not to bring: Anyone who brings alcohol or drugs will automatically be disqualified

description.html:
Working with Creative Imagination and the Alchemical Cycle

Paul Margrie

Saturday 17 June 2017                        10:00 – 16:00

Drake House, 44 St Georges Road, London SW19 4ED

Workshop cost: £120/ 10% discount for Wimbledon Guild counsellors/ Early-bird discount of 15% available until 4 March 2017


The Workshop:

This day will explore the therapeutic process using a model rooted in Alchemy that helps to orientate us in the evolving psyche of our clients.


We will be using the tools of Creative Imagination which are the defining feature of Transpersonal psychotherapy as it is practiced. This will involve the use of visualisations and meditations. We will share and explore dreams and each participant will be asked to create a personal myth.


The day will be a mix of teaching, sharing, experiential work and Q&A time.


The Trainer:

Paul Margrie is a Transpersonal therapist, supervisor and trainer with over 20 years of experience. He is a core staff member at CCPE, the foremost Transpersonal psychotherapy training in the UK.

description.html:
Healing the Traumatized Self: Clinical insights from interpersonal neurobiology

Margaret Wilkinson, analyst and author

Saturday 20 May 2017                        10:00 – 16:00

Drake House, 44 St Georges Road, London SW19 4ED

Workshop cost: £120/ 10% discount for Wimbledon Guild counsellors/ Early-bird discount of 15% available until 4 Feb 2017


The Workshop:

We very much need a theory and practice where the best of the old is conserved and yet where new insights are integrated and used effectively. I put forward the value of an interdisciplinary whole person psychodynamic approach that takes on board insights from attachment research, parent-infant psychotherapy research, trauma research and the neurobiology of emotion. I suggest that such an approach should no longer be considered an optional “extra” in the practice of psychotherapy and counselling. Rather it should become the foundation of our training and practice. How links are made between these and other contemporary fields of study regarding the making of mind, the insights that emerge and their strengths and limitations reward careful research, rather than speculation.

Cutting-edge research and clinical material will be explored in relation to the practical, clinical challenges of addressing and overcoming early relational trauma. Clinical material, including images, will be presented and there will be opportunities for discussion.


The Trainer:

Margaret Wilkinson is a training analyst in the Society of Analytical Psychology, London, a member of the
British Psychoanalytic Council, and of the editorial board of the Journal of Analytical Psychology. She leads neuroscience research reading and clinical seminars for The Northern School of Child and Adolescent Psychotherapy in Leeds, Cambridge and Edinburgh, and for The Institute of Mental Health at the University of Nottingham. She is the author of numerous papers and two books: ‘Coming into mind. The mind-brain relationship: a Jungian clinical perspective’ (2006, Routledge), and ‘Changing Minds in Therapy’ (2010, Norton Interpersonal Neurobiology series). She is in private practice in North Derbyshire, England.

description.html:
CBT for Beginners

Veronica Gioscia B.Sc. M.Sc.

Saturday 1 April 2017 10:00 – 13:00

Drake House, 44 St Georges Road, London SW19 4ED

Workshop cost: £60/ 10% discount for Wimbledon Guild counsellors/ Early-bird discount of 15% available until 25 February 2016


The Workshop:

The aim of the workshop will be to provide an overview of the basic principles of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, and how our thoughts, feelings, and behaviours are linked together and influence us.

Cognition is a key activity in our brain that helps us overcome difficulties, but sometimes traps us in rigid thinking patterns that revolve around the same points over and over. We often entertain circular thinking- we call it thinking but is a ruminative process.

This is a practical workshop that will teach specific techniques that will identify our unhelpful thoughts, what consequences they have on our mood and how to manage and reframe them, arriving at a more balanced view of our difficulties.

Other techniques will cover identifying cognitive errors and ways to challenge our negative cognitions.

Please come prepared with practical examples of your unhelpful thoughts or circular thinking patterns.



The Trainer:

Veronica Gioscia is a Counselling Psychologist in private practice working with adults and the main private health insurance companies since 2012. She is currently part of the MBT (Mentalization Based Theory) team at the Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust working with borderline personality disorder patients. She is a supervisor at the Wimbledon Guild.

Veronica started her career as a Criminal Lawyer in Italy working daily with people with extremely stressful psychological conditions. In 1998, Veronica moved to the UK and obtained a degree in Psychology and a post MSc in Counselling Psychology. From 2009 to 2011 she received specialist training from the Institute of Psychiatry and the Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust in Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT). In 2012, she obtained a Psychodynamic Psychotherapy MA from the University of Essex Tavistock and Portman NHS Trust.

She has worked for the NHS in various capacities. From 2005 to 2008, she was a member of Lambeth Primary Care Team working in various GP surgeries. From 2008 to 2011 she was a member of the first Increasing Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT) Service Team in the South London and the Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust.

From 2009 to 2011 she also worked in the Health Psychology Service at St Thomas’ Hospital in the outpatient department dealing with chronic health conditions.

Veronica is a Practicing Psychologist with the Health and Care Professional Council (HCPC) and Chartered Psychologist of the British Psychological Society.

description.html:
Silence Lends Integrity to Speech: transcending the opposites of speech and silence in the analytic dialogue

Anna Bravesmith

Saturday 6 May 2017                        10:00 – 16:00

Drake House, 44 St Georges Road, London SW19 4ED

Workshop cost: £120/ 10% discount for Wimbledon Guild counsellors/ Early-bird discount of 15% available until 29 January 2017


The Workshop:

In this presentation the interplay between silence and the spoken words used by analyst and patient will be explored within the context of clinical practice. Both psychotherapist and patient, it is argued, are engaged in a personal struggle to try to discover an integrative connection between silence, often experienced as nothingness, and speech, often experienced as suffocating or mendacious. Anna discusses a more complementary relationship between them in the spirit of Sontag’s observation that there is:

Still another use for silence: furnishing or aiding speech to attain its maximum integrity or seriousness. ( Susan Sontag,1966, p.20)


The uses of silence in aiding speech to attain integrity will be described with reference to two clinical vignettes and participants will be invited to bring their own examples of relevant clinical work. It will be argued that a Jungian perspective contributes a further, unique, insight through the concept of ‘transcendent function’ in which silence and speech are seen as opposites out of which new levels of meaning arise.


Plan for the day:
The morning will consist of theoretical input and large group discussion and the afternoon will consist of experiential work in small groups. Please bring your own examples of working with silence, or with patients who talk continuously, or any other variations on this theme.


The Trainer:

Anna Bravesmith is a Jungian analyst and member of the Society of Analytical Psychology, supervisor, supervisor of supervision, trainer and Training Clinical Coordinator at SAP. She also worked in NHS for 18 years, has published several papers and has a private practice.

The uses of silence in aiding speech to attain integrity will be described with reference to two clinical vignettes and participants will be invited to bring their own examples of relevant clinical work. It will be argued that a Jungian perspective contributes a further, unique, insight through the concept of ‘transcendent function’ in which silence and speech are seen as opposites out of which new levels of meaning arise.

Plan for the day:The morning will consist of theoretical input and large group discussion and the afternoon will consist of experiential work in small groups. Please bring your own examples of working with silence, or with patients who talk continuously, or any other variations on this theme.

The Trainer:
Anna Bravesmith is a Jungian analyst and member of the Society of Analytical Psychology, supervisor, supervisor of supervision, trainer and Training Clinical Coordinator at SAP. She also worked in NHS for 18 years, has published several papers and has a private practice.

name.html: Silence Lends Integrity to Speech: Transcending the opposites of speech and silence in the analytic dialogue

description.html:
A Pluralistic Framework for Counselling and Psychotherapy: Openness, Collaboration, and a Prizing of Diversity

Mick Cooper

Saturday 24 June 2017                        10:00 – 16:00

Drake House, 44 St Georges Road, London SW19 4ED

Workshop cost: £120/ 10% discount for Wimbledon Guild counsellors/ Early-bird discount of 15% available until 4 March 2017


The Workshop:

This workshop will introduce, and look at the practical implications of, a pluralistic approach to counselling and psychotherapy. This innovative new framework was developed by Mick Cooper and John McLeod (University of Abertay) in the 2000s, and has since been adopted by a number of practitioners and training institutes across the UK and internationally. The pluralistic approach is a collaborative, integrative perspective, deeply rooted in humanistic and person-centred values. Its fundamental premise is that client is unique, and therefore may need different things from therapy. On this basis, the pluralistic approach creates a framework in which practitioners can integrate a wide variety of understandings and methods into their practice. A key element of this pluralistic approach is shared decision making: talking to clients about what they want from therapy, and how they might most effectively be helped to get there. The workshop will include a mixture of theory input, skills practice, case examples and discussion. It will be draw on recent research into pluralism and shared decision-making in therapy, as well as Mick and John’s book Pluralistic Counselling and Psychotherapy (Sage, 2011) and the Handbook of Pluralistic Counselling and Psychotherapy (Sage, 2016).


The Trainer:

Mick Cooper is a Professor of Counselling Psychology at the University of Roehampton and a chartered counselling psychologist.  Mick is author and editor of a range of texts on person-centred, existential, and relational approaches to therapy, including Existential Therapies (Sage, 2003), Working at Relational Depth in Counselling and Psychotherapy (Sage, 2005, with Dave Mearns), and Pluralistic Counselling and Psychotherapy (Sage, 2011, with John McLeod). Mick has also led a range of research studies exploring the process and outcomes of humanistic counselling with young people.  Mick’s latest book is Existential psychotherapy and counselling: Contributions to a pluralistic practice (Sage, 2015). Mick lives in Brighton with his partner and four children.

description.html:
Inviting the Muse: Giving a conscious place to the imagination and creativity in therapy

Sarah Van Gogh

Saturday 4 March 2017                        10:00 – 16:00

Drake House, 44 St Georges Road, London SW19 4ED

Workshop cost: £110/ 10% discount for Wimbledon Guild counsellors/ Early-bird discount of 15% available until 29 January 2017


The Workshop:

“......poets may have more to teach us about schizophrenia than do psychiatry and psychopharmacology. After all, they have learned how to descend through the layers of our past to mesh the sensorial, imaginary, and symbolic in such a way as to convey unconscious knowledge.”

-Christopher Bollas


If we recognise that to be imaginative is not a fanciful luxury, and not exclusively for certain uniquely gifted individuals, but is rather a vital part of all human life, what could that mean when it comes to work in the therapy room?


This day will explore:

*what being creative and imaginative means to us as therapy practitioners

*the different ways we might harness creative energy in our work

*the effect on our clients when they feel that creativity is valued both intrapersonally (within them) and interpersonally (in the relationship with us).


There will be a chance to reflect on how the imagination can be understood in analytic, humanistic and transpersonal therapeutic paradigms.   There will also be experiential space, throughout the day, aimed at helping our imaginings bring us greater awareness about our own inner landscapes, the inner landscape of the client, and the crucial relationship between these two.


The Trainer:

Sarah Van Gogh works in private practice as a therapist and supervisor. She is also a tutor at the Revision Centre for Counselling & Psychotherapy, and a therapist and trainer at Survivors UK, a service that supports men who have experienced any form of sexual violation. 

She has worked in the fields of theatre, theatre-in-education, Montessori teaching, and community health outreach.

She is a published poet and writes a regular column for the BACP Private Practice Journal.  A long time ago she studied English at Cambridge.

Inviting the Muse: Giving a conscious place to the imagination and creativity in therapy

 

FAQs

 

What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event?

There is no parking at the Wimbledon Guild and limited on-street parking in the area.  However, there are a few pay car parks nearby.

 

What's the refund policy?

Visit our website here for information.

description.html:
Expressive Arts Therapy involves engaging clients in creative writing, poetry, music, and a variety of visual arts processes. Did you know this approach can expand to entire communities in need of healing and social change? In this talk, Danielle Drake shares her perspective on the impact of Expressive Arts in cultural engagements leading to social change. Her experiences are highlighted by spoken word poetry and stories of development as an African American woman connecting to the larger whole through engaging in creativity as an ongoing and necessary liberatory act.

Danielle Drake, MA/MS is a graduate of the CIIS Masters of Counseling Psychology, Expressive Arts Therapy program and now serves as Core Faculty/Assistant Professor in the program. She is currently pursuing a PhD in Clinical Psychology at Fielding Graduate University.  Danielle most recently contributed to the American Psychological Association publication, "Womanist and Mujerista Psychologies: Voices of Fire, Acts of Courage." Her co-authored chapter titled "Womanism, Creativity and Resistance: Making a Way Out of No Way" demonstrates the efficacy of using creativity and a Black Feminist (Womanist) framework to assist African-American women in therapy.  Her work as an Expressive Arts Therapist engages clients in creative writing, poetry, music, and visual arts processes.  She uses a humanistic and narrative informed theoretical approach that incorporates African, womanist, indigenous, and liberation psychologies with Emotion Focused Therapy, Narrative Therapy, and contemplative practices.

description.html:
WeBA Breakfast - "Reducing turnover and driving performance through employee engagement”

with 

MICHAEL KING, National Director: Human Resource Solutions and Data Analytics - Drake International

March 8th - Hyatt Place Edmonton - West 18004 100 Avenue


    -------   

WeBA Networking Breakfast Meetings are open to members and non-members, the WeBA networking breakfasts are an excellent opportunity to network, hear educational speakers, and to share in each other’s success. Join us on Dec 7th when our guest speaker will be, award-winning best-selling author, transformational speaker, blogger, and Certified Executive Coach Debra Kasowski.

Breakfast cost: Non-Members - $35.00   /  Members - $25.00

(If you missed the promo code email, request one from info@weba.org)

    -------   

About MICHAEL KING

Michael King is the National Director responsible for advancing Drake’s Human Resource Solutions and Data Analytics capabilities through Drake’s 19 Canadian offices and nine international offices. In this role Michael is responsible for designing and implementing both customized and application based data analytics solutions, empowering Human Resource departments.

Prior to assuming this strategic position, Michael served the Managing Director for a European based Data Analytics company developing customized operational and financial analytics solutions for companies such as the Bank of Montreal, Scotiabank etc. Michael has well established experience in building effective businesses through highly collaborative teams in Africa, the Middle East, Europe, Scandinavia and North America.

Michael has served in numerous international executive capacities for RBC Global Asset Management, Franklin Templeton Investments, STANLIB Asset Management, Innovation Norway and as a diplomat (Multi-Lateral Economics) for the government of South Africa.

A highlight in Michael’s experience is the opportunity which he enjoyed to work with former South African president, Nelson Mandela during South Africa’s return to the United Nations.

Michael holds a B.A (Hons.) degree in Development Economics and a degree in Industrial Psychology from the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, South Africa (1996) and has completed numerous executive leadership, financial and data analytics courses.

description.html:
Join us at Columbus's own Brother's Drake Meadery and Bar for a Date Night EXPERIENCE you won't forget!! Where you and your significant other will get to interact with International Published Author, Ms. Tonya Nanthavong and "N The Know" Talk Show Host, Nancy NiChole through the lessons found within "Lessons In Love: The Ebb and Flow of Intimacy" to help increase love, communication, appreciation, and the spice in your relationship.


The evening will include:

  • Live DJ
  • Menu selections from the Chefs Tasting Menu
  • Interactive activites
  • Couples Swag Bag with Lessons In Love Book, Bottle of Wine, and couples gifts


So join us as we engage on a love journey with music, dancing, food, drinks, and poetry that will tantalize and awaken, revitalize, and encourage your sensual and romantic side.

 


FAQs

Are there ID or minimum age requirements to enter the event?

Must be 21.

 

What is included with my ticket?

Each ticket includes event admission and dinner for one couple (2 people).


What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event?

Parking is on-site towards the side of the building.

 

What can I bring into the event?

BRING:

An open mind, fun and willing attitude, and alot of love.

DO NOT BRING:

Children as children's environments are not available.

Audio and visual recording devices are not permitted.

 

What's the refund policy?

All tickets are non-refundable. This event has very limited seating to encourage an intimate and romantic setting.


Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?

Yes, a printed or virtual copy of your ticket must be presented for admission into the event.

 

Is my registration fee or ticket transferrable? OR Is it ok if the name on my ticket or registration doesn't match the person who attends?

Yes, that's not a problem. Often the buyer of the ticket does not attend and/or purchases a ticket for someone else. If you are unable to attend, someone other than yourself can use your ticket. A printed or virtual copy of the ticket must be presented for admission into the event.


Have more Questions?

Call 614-962-8508 or 614-962-8006 if you have additional questions.

Join Drake Music for our final DMLab event. We will be showcasing 4 newly commissioned accessible music tools designed by our winning teams of disabled musicians and technologists!
Come along to find out more about the latest developments in accessible music technology and how you can be part of them.
This is a FREE musical performance and showcase event led by disabled artist, Kris Halpin. Kris will be performing with his amazing motion-tracking MiMU gloves, and showcasing the 4 winning commissions from Drake Music’s North West Lab Challenge. A must for all innovative musical Jedi everywhere!

description.html:
Drake Australia, in recognition of International Women’s Day, are proud to present:


‘WOMEN OF INFLUENCE: Lessons in Leadership’. 


In 2016 the Workplace Gender Equality Agency reported;

  • Men earn 23.1% more on average than women. 
  • 16.3% of CEOs are women.
  • 24.7% of Board Directors are women. 



What learnings can you take from successful women to alter the status quo?


Our panel of extraordinary women of influence will share their own insights and experiences, during a forum and will discuss:

  • Current workforce gender trends and statistics;
  • How they got to where they are today;
  • Leadership lessons learned along the way; and
  • Advice for driving positive change in the workplace. 



Panel members include: 


Jane Flemming – Former Olympian, Founder of ‘Live Life, Get Active’, recipient of an Order of Australia and featured as one of the 2016 Australian Financial Review & Westpac ‘100 Women of Influence’.


Belinda Brosnan – Founder & Managing Director of ‘HR Junction’, Executive coach and QLD winner of the 2015 Telstra Business Women’s Award. 


Janine Kewming – Director Philanthropy at ‘World Vision Australia’, extensive directorial experience across Marketing and Fundraising in NFPs and previous Manager within Drake Australia. 


Nina Marshall – Founder and Leadership Coach at ‘NCM Consulting’, Learning and Development Manager at the Recruitment and Consulting Services Association (RCSA) and finalist for the 2011 ANZ Coaching Institute Coaching Award.


We look forward to sharing our insight and experience at this complimentary breakfast panel discussion. RSVP now by clicking on the “REGISTER NOW” link.
